>>Interviewer:
Today we're talking with Dr. Kellie McElhaney

14.text:
who is an adjunct professor in the institute

18.text:
Haas School of Business at the University

21.text:
She also teaches at the UC Berkeley Center
for Executive Education.

26.text:
Her research in teaching are in three areas,
the economic and business value of investing

29.text:
in women, global macro trends in business
solutions, strategic corporate sustainability.

35.text:
Along with two other faculty members she is
developing a new gender equality initiative

39.text:
In 2013 Professor McElhaney was awarded the
Earl F Cheit Outstanding Teaching Award and

45.text:
in 2013 she received the Founder & Visionary
Award from Haas.

49.text:
Kellie keynotes for and consults to global
1,000 companies and organizations all over

54.text:
the world in developing, integrating, and
investing in woman in corporate sustainability

59.text:
She earned her BA from the University of North
Carolina, her MA from Ohio University, and

64.text: her PhD from the University of Michigan.

69.text:
I wanted to jump right into a topic that I
know you have done a lot of research on and

74.text:
that is the intersection of corporate social
responsibility and diversity.

80.text:

effect the environmental and social impact

86.text: Can you give us some examples of that?

>>Dr. McElhaney:
I became very interested in whether or not

90.text:
there was a correlation between having women
in leadership and the firm's corporate social

95.text:
responsibility performance both because my
traditional background is in the area of corporate

100.text:
social responsibility and corporate sustainability,
and because now I'm looking more and more

105.text:
at what are the effects if you get more women
into leadership.

108.text: I want to be really clear on that.

110.text:
It's not saying no men in leadership, but
just escalating the numbers of women in leadership.

116.text:
I did some research that looked at what the
database called ESG performance of the firm,

122.text:
which is environment, social, and governance
performance.

500 companies and how they perform environmentally,

130.text:
socially, and in their governance structure
and outcomes.

We went and looked at the number of women
on boards and our end was either zero women

139.text: on the board, or one or more.

141.text:
We didn't have a lot of robust data because
as of yet, only 16.1% of Fortune 500 companies

149.text: have even one woman on the board.

152.text:
What we found was that there was a correlation
between companies who had one or more women

157.text:
on the board and improved environmental performance
of the company, so higher investment in renewable

164.text:
energy, reduction of packaging, reduction
of water usage.

169.text:
Things that really improved both the financial
performance of the firm, because if you reduce

173.text:
waste, clearly you reduce wasting of money
as well, and things that really contributed

182.text:
The highest correlation that we found was
with environmental performance of the firm.

187.text:
The second highest was with improved social
performance of the firm.

191.text:
Things like food and beverage companies transitioning
from less healthy products, more sugar laden

200.text:
Someone like Indra Nooyi really trying to

more healthy waters, the snack portfolio into

Things like higher investment in talent management,
offering more transparent financial products.

Then finally governance was significantly
correlated above the level of statistical

The way that I talk about that is less misreport

646.text:
is to surround ourselves by people just like

664.text: is there a lack of awareness.

683.text: and start with a business case.

All of my research in consulting and teaching

689.text:
perform better when you have a higher level

There's a great study that shows that teams

700.text:
number of women and men in the room show more

707.text:
In other words, they perform the task much

723.text:
The share price performs better particularly

732.text:
valid financial strategy, they pay the debt

You can't be what you can't see, so if there

745.text:
because you don't see yourself in that leadership
